metadata.title: Expansion of Maratha Power
metadata.subject: History
metadata.description: The transformation of the Maratha Swaraj into a vast empire under the Peshwas ‚Äî Balaji Vishwanath's political genius, Bajirao I's undefeated military campaigns across India, the vision of striking at the heart of Delhi, and the growth of the Maratha confederacy.

concepts.title: The Peshwa System
concepts.content: The Peshwa was originally the Prime Minister in Shivaji's Ashtapradhan ‚Äî one of eight ministers serving the Chhatrapati. After Shivaji's time, the Peshwa position became increasingly powerful. Under Shahu Maharaj, the Peshwa effectively became the executive head of the Maratha government, while the Chhatrapati remained the ceremonial and symbolic head. The Peshwa's seat was at Pune (specifically Shaniwarwada, the famous Peshwa palace). This shift of effective power from Satara (the Chhatrapati's seat) to Pune (the Peshwa's seat) marked a fundamental transformation of the Maratha state. The Peshwas were Brahmin administrators of the Chitpavan community ‚Äî highly educated, skilled in both administration and diplomacy. Under capable Peshwas like Balaji Vishwanath and Bajirao I, the Maratha empire expanded rapidly across India.
examples: Under Bajirao I, the Peshwa had more day-to-day power than the Chhatrapati ‚Äî though Shahu Maharaj fully supported Bajirao's campaigns.
Shaniwarwada palace in Pune (built 1732) became the de facto capital of the Maratha empire under Peshwa governance.
The Peshwa's office managed all military, financial, and diplomatic affairs of the empire.
keyPoints: Peshwa: originally Prime Minister in Shivaji's Ashtapradhan.
After Shivaji's time, Peshwa became effective executive ruler while Chhatrapati was symbolic head.
Peshwa seat: Pune (Shaniwarwada); Chhatrapati seat: Satara.
Peshwas were Chitpavan Brahmin administrators ‚Äî highly educated in governance.
Capable Peshwas transformed Maratha Swaraj into a pan-Indian empire.
concepts.funFact: Shaniwarwada palace was built in 1732 and was the Peshwa's seat of power. It burned down in a mysterious fire in 1828 ‚Äî now only its massive entrance gate stands. The cause of the fire remains a historical mystery!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 10, Page 44

concepts.title: Balaji Vishwanath ‚Äî The First Effective Peshwa
concepts.content: Balaji Vishwanath (Peshwa from 1713-1720) is considered the founder of effective Peshwa governance. He was not primarily a military man ‚Äî his genius was political and diplomatic. He used alliances, diplomacy, and financial management to strengthen the Maratha position. His most significant achievement was the Treaty of 1719 with the Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar ‚Äî negotiated through masterful diplomacy after Maratha military victories. This treaty secured Shahu Maharaj's formal recognition as Chhatrapati, gave the Marathas the right to collect chauth (a quarter of revenue) from the Deccan, and recognized the Maratha territories. Balaji Vishwanath also reorganized Maratha finances, which had been strained by decades of war. He set the stage for the explosive expansion under his son Bajirao I, who would become the greatest military commander in Maratha history.
examples: The Treaty of 1719 was Balaji Vishwanath's masterpiece ‚Äî he negotiated from a position of military strength but used diplomacy to formalize gains.
Chauth collection rights from the Deccan gave Marathas enormous revenue without having to directly administer those regions.
His financial reorganization of the Maratha state created the resource base that funded Bajirao I's ambitious campaigns.
keyPoints: Balaji Vishwanath: Peshwa 1713-1720, genius political and financial administrator.
Treaty of 1719 with Mughal Emperor: formal recognition of Shahu as Chhatrapati.
Secured Marathas' right to collect chauth (25% of revenue) from Deccan territories.
Reorganized Maratha finances ‚Äî created resource base for future expansion.
Father of Bajirao I ‚Äî built the platform for the greatest Peshwa's expansion.
concepts.funFact: Chauth literally means 'one-fourth' ‚Äî Marathas collected 25% of revenue from territories they protected but didn't directly administer. This revenue-sharing model was a creative alternative to direct conquest and helped Maratha power spread across India without the full cost of administration!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 10, Pages 44-45

concepts.title: Bajirao I ‚Äî The Greatest Military Genius
concepts.content: Bajirao I (Peshwa 1720-1740) is widely considered the greatest military commander in Maratha history and one of the finest cavalry commanders in world history. He never lost a single battle in his career ‚Äî an extraordinary record. His strategic vision was expressed in one memorable phrase: 'Let us strike at the trunk (Delhi) ‚Äî the branches will fall by themselves.' Rather than wastefully capturing and administering every individual region, Bajirao believed in striking at the center of Mughal power to break the empire's authority. His campaigns ranged from Gujarat to Malwa, Bundelkhand, and Rajputana. In 1737, Bajirao's cavalry appeared near Delhi itself ‚Äî the Mughal emperor was terrified and could not protect his own capital. The Battle of Bhopal (1737) was a complete Maratha victory against the Mughal army. By the time Bajirao died at age 40 (1740), Maratha power extended across a vast portion of northern India.
examples: Bajirao's cavalry could cover up to 100 km per day ‚Äî an extraordinary pace that let him strike enemies before they could react or organize defenses.
His appearance near Delhi in 1737 was so shocking that the Mughal emperor sent urgent letters to his governors for help ‚Äî but Bajirao had already won at Bhopal and returned.
Bajirao defeated the Nizam of Hyderabad multiple times ‚Äî the Nizam eventually signed peace treaties acknowledging Maratha supremacy.
keyPoints: Bajirao I: Peshwa 1720-1740, never lost a single battle.
Strategic vision: 'Strike at the trunk (Delhi) ‚Äî branches will fall.'
Campaigns in Gujarat, Malwa, Bundelkhand, Rajputana, and near Delhi.
Battle of Bhopal (1737): decisive Maratha victory over Mughals near Delhi.
Died 1740 at age 40 ‚Äî Maratha power now spanned much of northern India.
concepts.funFact: Bajirao I rode a horse reportedly named 'Masoba' ‚Äî and his cavalry's speed was so legendary that Mughal spies once reported that the Maratha army had appeared in a place 200 miles away from where they had last seen it ‚Äî in just two days! The Mughals called his cavalry raids 'cheetah attacks'!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 10, Page 45

concepts.title: Expansion Across India
concepts.content: Under Bajirao I and the subsequent Peshwas, Maratha power expanded dramatically across India. Key territorial expansions: Gujarat ‚Äî Maratha forces established influence; Malwa (central India) ‚Äî Marathas controlled this strategic region; Bundelkhand (central India) ‚Äî Marathas aided local chiefs; Rajputana ‚Äî Maratha influence spread; Punjab ‚Äî Maratha power eventually reached Attock (near present-day Pakistan). This expansion was not always through direct military conquest. Marathas collected 'chauth' (protection taxes) from territories they didn't directly administer. Regional chiefs often asked for Maratha help and in return accepted Maratha suzerainty. The Marathas also placed their commanders as governors in some regions. By the mid-18th century, Maratha commanders were deciding who sat on many thrones across India ‚Äî a testament to the empire's extraordinary reach.
examples: Maratha forces reached Attock in Punjab (near present-day Pakistan) ‚Äî completing Shivaji's dream of Swaraj reaching from sea to sea.
In Rajputana, many Rajput kings accepted Maratha protection ‚Äî paying chauth in exchange for military support.
Maratha governors (like the Holkars in Indore and Scindias in Gwalior) built their own cities and palaces ‚Äî leaving architectural heritage across northern India.
keyPoints: Maratha expansion covered: Gujarat, Malwa, Bundelkhand, Rajputana, and Punjab.
Maratha power reached Attock in Punjab by mid-18th century.
Expansion through both direct conquest and chauth collection system.
Regional chiefs accepted Maratha suzerainty in exchange for military protection.
Maratha commanders became kingmakers across much of northern India.
concepts.funFact: When Maratha forces reached Attock fort on the Indus River in Punjab, they reportedly had a victory celebration and brought water from the Indus River back to Pune to show Shahu Maharaj ‚Äî a symbolic fulfillment of the dream of Maratha power spanning all of India!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 10, Pages 45-46

concepts.title: The Maratha Confederacy
concepts.content: As the Maratha empire expanded, the Peshwa at Pune could not directly administer all the conquered territories. Instead, capable Maratha commanders were given control of specific regions with considerable autonomy. This created the Maratha Confederacy ‚Äî a group of powerful Maratha houses, each controlling a region, all nominally under the Chhatrapati and Peshwa but effectively semi-independent. The major Maratha houses of the confederacy were: Holkars (Indore) ‚Äî founded by Malhar Rao Holkar; Scindias/Shinde (Gwalior) ‚Äî founded by Ranoji Shinde; Bhosales (Nagpur) ‚Äî ruling central and eastern India; Gaekwads (Baroda) ‚Äî ruling Gujarat; Peshwas (Pune) ‚Äî controlling Maharashtra and overall coordination. Each house had its own army, treasury, and administration. This decentralized structure allowed rapid expansion but also created rivalry and division ‚Äî which would prove fatal at the Third Battle of Panipat.
examples: Ahilyabai Holkar (of the Holkar house) became one of the greatest rulers of 18th century India ‚Äî famous for her just rule, massive temple renovations, and care for subjects.
The Scindia house of Gwalior maintained power until 1947 ‚Äî one of the most durable Maratha dynasties.
The lack of unified command among these houses was a key reason for the disaster at the Third Battle of Panipat (1761).
keyPoints: Maratha Confederacy: semi-independent Maratha houses controlling different regions.
Major houses: Holkars (Indore), Scindias/Shinde (Gwalior), Bhosales (Nagpur), Gaekwads (Baroda), Peshwas (Pune).
Each house had own army, treasury, and administration.
Decentralized structure allowed rapid expansion but created internal rivalries.
The lack of unity would prove costly at the Third Battle of Panipat.
concepts.funFact: Ahilyabai Holkar of the Holkar dynasty of Indore is often called 'the philosopher queen.' She renovated Hindu temples across India (including Somnath, Kashi Vishwanath, and dozens of others), built roads, rest houses, and wells, and is celebrated as one of India's greatest female rulers ‚Äî her portrait appears on a postage stamp and many public places in Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh honor her name!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 10, Page 46

test.question: Under the Peshwa system, where did effective executive power shift to?

options.D: From the army to the navy

test.explanation: The Chhatrapati remained at Satara as the symbolic head of the Maratha state, but effective executive power shifted to the Peshwa at Pune. The Peshwa handled all military, financial, and diplomatic affairs.

test.question: What is 'chauth'?

options.C: A 25% revenue tax that Marathas collected from territories under their protection
options.D: A religious ceremony performed by Peshwas

test.explanation: Chauth (meaning 'one-fourth') was a 25% tax on revenue that Marathas collected from territories they protected. It was a key source of revenue and a way to extend influence without direct administration.

test.question: Bajirao I's famous strategic principle was:

options.A: Defend every fort at all costs
options.B: Strike at the trunk (Delhi) ‚Äî the branches will fall
options.D: Build a fort before attacking any enemy

test.explanation: Bajirao I's strategic vision was to strike at the center of power (Delhi/Mughal heartland) rather than slowly conquering individual regions. He believed that if the center fell, the periphery would follow ‚Äî like cutting the trunk of a tree makes all branches fall.

test.question: The Battle of Bhopal in 1737 was fought between:

options.B: Marathas and the Nizam of Hyderabad
options.C: Marathas and a Mughal army ‚Äî resulting in a Maratha victory near Delhi

test.explanation: The Battle of Bhopal (1737) was a decisive Maratha victory over the Mughal army near Delhi. It showed that Maratha power had reached the Mughal heartland ‚Äî a shocking development for the declining Mughal empire.

test.question: Which Maratha house controlled Gwalior?
test.explanation: The Scindias (also written as Shinde) were the Maratha house that controlled Gwalior in northern India. They were one of the major houses in the Maratha confederacy.

test.question: How far north did Maratha power eventually reach?

options.C: Up to Attock in Punjab (near present-day Pakistan)

test.explanation: At the peak of Maratha power, their forces reached Attock fort on the Indus River in Punjab (near present-day Pakistan). This represented the maximum northern expansion of Maratha power.

test.question: Balaji Vishwanath's greatest diplomatic achievement was:

options.A: Signing a peace treaty with the British
options.B: Treaty of 1719 with the Mughal Emperor giving formal recognition to Shahu and chauth rights

test.explanation: Balaji Vishwanath negotiated the Treaty of 1719 with Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar ‚Äî securing formal recognition of Shahu as Chhatrapati and Maratha rights to collect chauth from the Deccan. This was the diplomatic cornerstone of Maratha expansion.

test.question: Which of the following was a major weakness of the Maratha confederacy structure?

options.A: The houses were too small to maintain armies
options.B: Internal rivalries and lack of unified command ‚Äî which proved fatal at Panipat
options.C: The Peshwas were not educated enough
options.D: The confederacy had no access to the sea

test.explanation: The decentralized Maratha confederacy allowed rapid expansion, but also created rivalry and coordination problems. The lack of unified command contributed significantly to the Maratha defeat at the Third Battle of Panipat in 1761.

keyConcepts: Peshwa system: Peshwa became effective ruler; Chhatrapati symbolic head at Satara
Balaji Vishwanath: first effective Peshwa, Treaty of 1719, chauth rights
Bajirao I: greatest military genius, never lost a battle, 'Strike the trunk'
Battle of Bhopal (1737): Maratha victory near Delhi
Maratha power reached Attock in Punjab
Maratha confederacy: Holkars, Scindias, Bhosales, Gaekwads, Peshwas
commonMisconceptions: Students sometimes think the Peshwas replaced the Chhatrapati ‚Äî the Chhatrapati remained sovereign; the Peshwas were executives under them.
Chauth is sometimes understood as a tribute paid to a foreign power ‚Äî it was actually a tax collected by Marathas from territories they protected.
Students may not realize how fast Bajirao's cavalry moved ‚Äî his speed was a strategic weapon, not just an advantage.
The confederacy is sometimes seen as a unified empire ‚Äî in reality each house had significant autonomy which created both strength and vulnerability.
realWorldExamples: Shaniwarwada palace in Pune can still be visited ‚Äî though only the gate remains after the mysterious 1828 fire.
The Holkar dynasty's legacy in Indore includes many public buildings and the famous Rajwada palace ‚Äî still standing today.
Gwalior fort, the seat of the Scindia house, is one of India's finest forts and a UNESCO heritage site.
